Summary The “Bangkok Declarations” highlight key strategies to reduce the cancer burden in Asia. Recognizing the role of lifestyle factors like tobacco use, unhealthy diets, and inactivity, they advocate for public health initiatives promoting healthier communities. Environmental risks must also be addressed to enhance prevention strategies. Vaccination programs targeting cancer-causing viruses are emphasized for reducing incidence rates. However, limited access to cancer screening and early detection services remains a challenge, requiring improvements to boost early intervention and patient outcomes. The financial burden of cancer treatment is critical, necessitating cost-effective therapies and financial support systems. Mental health support for patients and caregivers is essential for holistic care. Digital health technologies and AI offer promise for improving diagnosis and treatment in resource-limited settings. Collaboration among stakeholders is vital, with culturally sensitive approaches ensuring equitable care. Research should focus on lifestyle, environmental factors, innovative prevention, and access to care for effective cancer control. The most common cancers were lung, breast, and colorectal. Approximately 58% of global cancer deaths occurred in Asia, primarily due to lung, liver, and gastrointestinal cancers. 1 2 3 4 Theme 1: epidemiology and risk factors Statement 1 Lifestyle factors such as tobacco use, unhealthy diet, and lack of physical activity contribute significantly to the burden of cancer in the region. Problem Lifestyle risk factors, such as tobacco use, unhealthy diet, and lack of physical activity, contribute significantly to the high and increasing burden of common cancers in the region. 1 , 5 6 , 7 8 9 , 10 7 , 11 7 , 12 13 14 , 15 14 , 15 7 , 16 17 18 19 20 21 22 Solution In response to these challenges, the Asian National Cancer Centers Alliance (ANCCA) has developed comprehensive, evidence-based guidelines to mitigate the cancer burden in member states. 23 24 24 25 , 26 25 25 Statement 2 The impact of environmental factors on cancer incidence and mortality needs to be further explored and addressed. Problem On the other hand, environmental factors, such as infections caused by Helicobacter pylori 1 , 5 27 28 29 7 , 11 30 31 , 32 Solution To mediate the burden of cancer attributable to environmental factors, the ANCCA also advocates for reducing environmental pollutants such as air pollution, pesticides, and radiation; participating in vaccination programs for Hepatitis B and HPV; and undergoing cancer screenings for bowel, breast, cervical, and other cancers, managing stress, protecting against UV radiation, avoiding unsafe sex, and cautiously using hormone replacement therapy (HRT). 7 Statement 3 Innovative approaches in cancer prevention, including vaccination against cancer-causing viruses, can help reduce the disease burden. Problem Cancer prevention through emerging technologies and innovative approaches presents transformative opportunities for Southeast Asia's evolving healthcare landscape. While traditional prevention methods remain important, technological innovations are revolutionizing preventive strategies across ASEAN nations. 33 34 Solution Asian countries may consider using innovative approaches that have been tested in other countries. For example, in China, a multicenter randomized controlled trials has reported the benefit of using AI-assisted colonoscopy in detecting adenoma among asymptomatic individuals. 35 36 37 38 39 , 40 Theme 2: healthcare delivery and access Statement 4 Access to cancer screening and early detection services remains a significant challenge in many countries across the region. Problem Barriers to cancer screening include lack of awareness or education, inconvenience, fear of pain, lack of time, and cultural perceptions. 41 42 , 43 44 45 5 46 47 Solution To mediate the abovementioned difficulties in local healthcare services, the Thailand government has decided to focus on district and subdistrict levels of health infrastructure since the fourth National Economic and Social Development Plan in 1977. 48 49 50 51 , 52 53 54 55 Problem Another challenge related to cancer screening that many Asian countries face is the increasing incidence of cancer among younger generations. For instance, female breast cancer incidence rates have significantly increased from 1990 to 2021 among patients aged between 15 and 39 across all countries in Southeast Asia, with highest increase observed in Thailand, Singapore, and Malaysia. 56 57 58 59 60 Solution Therefore, in Asia, a one-size-fits-all approach of lowering the screening age to address the rapidly increasing burden of early-onset cancers may not be an effective or efficient strategy. In contrast, Hong Kong's Centre for Health Protection categorizes women into high risk, moderate risk, and average risk based on personalized risk factors to determine the appropriate starting age for mammography screening. 61 Statement 5 The cost of cancer treatment and care poses a significant financial burden on individuals and healthcare systems in the region. Problem Asia, encompassing both high-income countries like Australia, Japan, and Singapore, as well as low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), faces significant financial challenges regarding cancer treatment. A nationwide multisite study found that approximately 50% of cancer patients reported experiencing financial toxicity, which negatively impacted their quality of life and treatment adherence. 62 , 63 64 65 66 66 , 67 68 69 70 Solution To address these challenges, a multifaceted approach is essential, including implementing value-based pricing models, expanding insurance coverage, increasing access to subsidized medications, improving data collection for evidence-based policy making, and emphasizing prevention and early detection strategies. Adopting the Comprehensive Score for Financial Toxicity (COST) could serve as an effective approach to reporting financial toxicity in Asia. This is a validated tool that assesses patients' perceived financial burden, evaluates their coping mechanisms, and measures the impact of costs on their quality of life. 71 72 73 73 Statement 6 Digital health technologies have the potential to revolutionize care delivery and potential monitoring in resource-limited settings. Problem Emerging digital health technologies have significant potential for enhancing cancer care delivery. Successful examples have shown that digital health technologies can be widely used at multiple stages of cancer care, including prevention, screening, and treatment. For instance, digital health technologies can provide information on healthy lifestyles to educate patients and support behavioral change. 74 75 , 76 Solution The development of digital health apps may refer to some successfully examples from Asian regions. The Hong Kong government launched the eHealth App to support patient healthcare, and a study found that type 2 diabetes patients who used its Health Management Module achieved more optimal HbA1c levels across all subgroups. 77 78 , 79 80 81 Theme 3: patient support and community engagement Statement 7 Cultural beliefs and practices influence attitudes towards cancer screening, treatment choices, and end-of-life care in Asia. Problem Cultural beliefs and practices significantly influence attitudes towards cancer screening, treatment choices, and end-of-life care across Asia. Addressing these cultural aspects is crucial for developing effective global health strategies tailored to diverse populations. For example, women in the region often face barriers such as modesty and embarrassment when considering breast and cervical cancer screenings, leading to low uptake in some areas. 82 83 84 83 85 85 , 86 87 88 89 Solution Among the fundamental aspects of cancer care is the need to acknowledge patients' cultural backgrounds. This is crucial across the spectrum of cancer care, from screening to end-of-life care. Women in Asia often face dilemmas in breast and cervical cancer screening uptake due to modesty concerns. 90 , 91 92 , 93 94 , 95 96 , 97 Statement 8 Providing access to mental health support for cancer patients and their caregivers is crucial for improving overall quality of life during and after treatment. Problem Patients facing cancer experience multifaceted stressors that impact their physical and mental health, often leading to a decline in overall quality of life. Perceived stigma related to cancer is considered to be more prevalent and severe in Asia, as Asian cultures are generally more conservative and stringent compared to the West. 98 99 98 , 99 Solution Mental health support, particularly through social interactions and solidarity, has been shown to alleviate these effects and enhance quality of life. Studies highlight that perceived social support significantly improves outcomes among cancer patients, often yielding greater benefits compared to the general population. 100 101 Problem Caregivers, who are increasingly involved in outpatient and ambulatory cancer care settings, also face a decline in quality of life due to the stress of caregiving. In Asia, the role of caregiver is usually played by family members, mostly women, and is motivated by the sociocultural values of filial piety. 102 103 102 103 104 Solution Social support, including family involvement, can help mitigate these challenges. 105 102 106 Statement 9 Collaboration between researchers, policymakers, healthcare providers, and community stakeholders is essential for developing effective cancer control programs. Problem Modern cancer care encompasses three critical facets: clinical medicine, approaches to care, and systems-level solutions. 107 90 , 108 92 , 94 Solution The factors influencing the local burden of cancer are often interconnected and shaped by multiple sectors, including healthcare, education, environment, and socioeconomics. Consequently, effective cancer control necessitates a collaborative approach, integrating health education, prevention, clinical trials, disease registries, patient screening, and care. 109 110 91 91 91 111 112 113 109 , 114 Theme 4: innovation and research Statement 10 The integration of artificial intelligence and machine learning in cancer diagnosis and treatment planning has the potential to improve clinical outcomes. Problem Regarding cancer diagnosis and treatment, the decision-making process should be tailored to a patient's phenotype and ability to respond to specific treatments. Treatment response may vary by detection, management, aggressiveness, and recurrence complexities. AI has the immediate potential to improve disease diagnosis and assessment through accurate interpretation of radiographic imaging. 115 Solution Deep learning models have accurately identified and diagnosed patterns in radiographic imaging. 116 115 117 118 119 120 Problem However, it is crucial to ensure the generalizability of such approaches and avoid overreliance on one-size-fits-all solutions. 121 Solution The localization of AI includes ensuring marginalized populations to be fully represented in data collection, model training, and implementation processes, as well as verifying the applicability and effectiveness of these technologies for vulnerable groups. 122 Statement 11 Addressing healthcare workforce shortages and enhancing training programs for oncology professionals are crucial for meeting the growing demand for cancer care. Problem Cancer incidence rises as the population ages. According to the American Cancer Society, an aging population greatly contributes to the rising incidence of cancer. 123 124 125 126 127 128 129 Solution The healthcare workforce shortages may be addressed with a more comprehensive training curriculum that incorporates new approaches to improve diagnosis, treatment, and monitoring, especially in LMICs. 130 , 131 132 133 134 126 128 Statement 12 Multisectoral approaches that address social determinants of health are essential for reducing the burden of cancer and improving health equity in the region. Problem Social determinants of health (SDH) are “the non-medical factors that influence health outcomes”. They are the conditions in which people are born, grow, work, live, and age, and the wider set of forces and systems shaping the conditions of daily life. These forces and systems include economic policies and systems, development agendas, social norms, social policies, and political systems. 135 136 137 138 Solution In order to address health equity, an understanding of the classification of SDH is important. Inequities occur due to three major factors: structural inequities and social injustice, institutional environment, living environment which can be classified as social needs. 139 139 140 141 142 139 143 144 144 144 Contributors Junjie Huang, Claire Chenwen Zhong, Abubakar Sunusi Ishak, Bukola Titilope Lawal, Chidinma Nelson Orji, Edmar S.
